Award.AwardTitle: NEESR Planning/Collaborative Research: Engineered Timber Structural Systems for Seismically Resilient Tall Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
To enable resilient, eight to fourteen story, timber buildings in regions of high seismicity in the United States, this planning grant combines innovative concepts in seismic load resisting systems with a new form of a mass timber structural component, called cross laminated timber (CLT), to research three potential structural systems for resilient, tall CLT building construction: (a) single-story, pre-stressed re-centering walls, (b) multi-story, segmental rocking walls, and (c) deformable floor diaphragms with supplemental damping devices. These systems will be distributed vertically along the height of the building, combining deformable panels or layers with relatively rigid and stiff ones, to leverage CLT behavior, enable rapid construction, and limit the impact of higher modes. Based on their performance in component-level testing and system-level simulation conducted as part of this research, promising systems that are economically competitive will be selected for full-scale experimental investigation in follow-on research. This planning phase research will generate fundamental knowledge on resilient, multi-story panelized systems that have the potential to transform the seismic design of taller buildings in general.

As urban densification occurs in U.S. regions of high seismicity, there is a natural demand for tall buildings that can survive large earthquakes with minimal damage and interruption. CLT is a naturally sustainable material that has been used in Europe and Australia to rapidly construct multi-story buildings. However, existing multi-story CLT constructions were limited to regions of low seismicity because there is no seismic design methodology for tall CLT buildings worldwide. In the U.S. Pacific Northwest, there is significant interest in utilizing CLT in eight to fourteen story residential and commercial buildings due to its appeal as a potential locally sourced, sustainable, and economically competitive building material. With combined expertise from the research and design community, this project will address this societal need by prototyping three potential structural systems that are suitable for tall CLT buildings in high seismicity regions, comparing their performance through experimentation and simulation, and developing performance-based seismic design methods for their implementation. Once the optimal systems are selected in this study and verified at full-scale in subsequent research, it is envisioned that a resilient, tall CLT building will become an option for west coast cities in about six to eight years. In addition to providing research training for students working on the project, the project will deliver educational resources to introduce this new sustainable building type to students, stakeholders, and the general public. Data from this project will be archived and made available to the public through the NEES data repository. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project “NEESR Planning/Collaborative Research: Engineered Timber Structural Systems for Seismically Resilient Tall Buildings” was conducted collaboratively by five academic institutions, including Lehigh University, Colorado School of Mines, Washington State University,  University of Washington, and Colorado State University and reached the following outcomes:

Intellectual outcomes: Two innovative structural components suitable for protecting tall wood buildings during large earthquake events were prototyped and tested, including a prestressed rocking wall component and a sliding deformable floor system (see Figure 1). Both systems are made out of cross laminated timber, a new heavy timber building material that has been used to build wood buildings up to 10-story in low seismic regions. The innovative structural components developed in this project can potentially be installed in a multi-story (8 to 20 story) wood building to enable the structure to survive large earthquakes with minimal damage. This is a timely effort, as the U.S. Tall Wood Building Competition recently announced a winning project of a tall CLT building in Portland, Oregon. The research project also proposed new performance targets that can be adopted in the design of new tall wood buildings in earthquake-prune regions. The proposed performance target includes three levels of performance options for the designer and stakeholder that depend on budget and damage tolerance in an earthquake. The research findings were disseminated through multiple journal and conference publications, the NEESHub website, and the NEESCLT project website. Finally, as a planning research project, a new proposal is under development using the planning project results to enable the design of resilient tall wood buildings for regions with high seismicity.

Broader impact outcomes: Graduate students from five universities gained valuable research experience through the testing and modeling of the innovative building components developed in this project. Some of the graduate students are from under-represented groups in STEM. The project reached out extensively to the design, wood manufacturing, and local building code implementation communities in the Pacific Northwest through a well attended workshop and structural testing that was open to the public. The PIs presented the research findings in multiple conferences and convention events, including the World Conference on Timber Engineering, ASCE Structures Congress, and Annual Convention of the Structural Engineering Association of California (SEAOC). The CLT rocking wall system developed in this study was considered by a structural engineering firm for the U.S. Tall Wood Building Competition, and was the winning project as one of the potential systems to adopt in seismic design. The results from this project helped to increase the momentum of a new sustainable construction material for tall buildings in the U.S.
